Laing discusses sexual roles
By ALLEN SHORT
Speaking to a standing room
only audience at Goucher College
last Friday, British
psychiatrist-author R.D. Laing
asserted that the modern
relationship between man and
woman is based on a legacy of
prejudice, fear, and resultant
insecurity.
"There's something curious in
the relationships I've seen in my
world travels," said Laing. "In
Ceylon, the Buddhist monks
refuse to look at women,as if the
sight of a woman is either evil or
bad luck." Laing disclosed that
while touring India, he had
known only two men who were
not afraid of women.
Similar observations in Europe
and America have led the
psychiatrist to the conclusion
that some type of fear of women
is a universal characteristic of
man.

The reasons for this
"extraordinary state of affairs",
Laing suggested, can be traced far
back into history. He noted that
in Western culture, Inquisition
era textbooks taught that Lucifer
had been given earth as his
domain by God. Lucifer's powers
had been confined to those of
temptation, however, and his
influence could not have been
responsible for the various
phenomena such as'birth defects,
impotence, insanity, and the
alleged changing of men into
animals which existed in the
world of the Inquisitors.
Moon Goddess
These occurrences, said Laing,
were believed to be the results of
the powers of Luna, the Pagan
moon Goddess, as she exercised
her will through cer-woman, or
witches.
The result of the Inquisition
teachings was to spur a concerted

effort to find Luna's cohorts,
according to Laing, which led to
the infamous witch hunts which
swept Europe and America
throughout the sixteenth and
seventeenth centuries and
resulted in the tortuous deaths of
several million women.
Laing asserted that such
ignorance is alive and well today,
even in modern psychology.
Using the professional writings of
Sigmund Freud as an example of
"a continuing source of sexual
prejudice and fear," Laing
specifically referred to Freud's
essay on women and female
psychology to support his
contention.
"According to the essay," said
Laing, "when one thinks he is
persecuting women, it is called
paranoia. If one really is
persecuting women, but does not
realize it, according to Freud.
there is no name for it!"

Dr. Archie S. Golden.

prepare people for the Columbia
Institutions, while at the same
time act as a pilot study for the
evaluation of the costs, care, and
efficiency provided by such
health maintenance
organizations.
By analyzing previous studies,
administrators have been able to
calculate the number and types
of people needed for health
maintenance organizations, said
Dr. Douglas A. Fenderson,
director of HEW's special
programs. "The purpose of this
grant is to use that experience to
devise training programs for these
new types of personnel."
The training programs will
vary in length from two to six
months and will utilize the
facilities of both Columbia and
the Johns Hopkins Medical
Institutions, Golden indicated.
Participants in the program will

receive no special degree for
participation in the program, but
the possibility of some kind of
credit in the future is being
investigated, he noted.
Graduates of the program will
work as family health associates
in the Columbia Medical Program
which serves approximately
12,000 residents of Baltimore
and Howard counties. As health

half-nurse and half-general

jobs as workers in inpatient,
ambulatory and coronary care
units. These practitioners will
also be responsible for
conducting medical history
interviews with incoming patients
and initial emergency room
treatment.

insecurity.

the relationships I've seen in my
world travels," said Laing. "In
Ceylon, the Buddhist monks
refuse to look at women,as if the
sight of a woman is either evil or
bad luck." Laing disclosed that
while touring India, he had
known only two men who were
not afraid of women.
Similar observations in Europe
and America have led the
psychiatrist to the conclusion
that some type of fear of women
is a universal characteristic of
man.

back into history. He noted that
in Western culture, Inquisition

influence could not have been
responsible for the various
phenomena such as'birth defects,
impotence, insanity, and the
alleged changing of men into
animals which existed in the
world of the Inquisitors.
Moon Goddess

were believed to be the results of

Council (HAC) passed a measure which will limit all

enormous concern on the part of the administration in
regards to those issues on campus that bother the
students, actually reflects the group's traditional role
as a rubber stamp for sanctifying policy decisions
handed down from the administration. Certainly the
presence of solicitors on campus is no burning issue on

restrictions on solicitation are the policy statements of
DEan Owen and other administrators delivered to the
HAC for its approval.
In the final estimation, the restrictions on
solicitation are another example of a decree from the
administration "to protect the students" from a
non-existent menace which was ratified by another in
a series of meaningless advisory councils.
